column4: I thought I'd try again. Can anyone help me with usb support for an iPod?  It's not mounting.
Have you added it to fstab? That may stop hotplug/udev/whatever from mounting it
I don't know what the device name is.  It doesn't show up in dmesg
thx for the reply btw
It will be /dev/sdX (a, b, c, d, etc, depending on how many drives you have that are USB, SCSI or SATA)
I think iPods use the second partition for data storage if you want to mount it manually or put it in fstab, but that may stop it from automounting when you plug it in
can I mount it without adding a line to fstab?  Also, is there an easy way of finding out how many drives I have that are USB, SCSI etc?
I would advise against the fstab way, since it is not a permanent drive. "fdisk -l" should show all partitions on all drives, so you should be able to guess whichis which
Thanks for the advice. I'll let you know how it goes.
fdisk -l only shows my physical disk drives.  Does that mean my usb isn't properly configured?
If the iPod is plugged in it should show up. Try "lsusb" I think
Bus 002 Device 001: ID 0000:0000
Wow, that seems really helpful :)
Try "ls /dev/sd*" and see what happens (BTW, is your hard drive USB, SCSI or SATA, or just plain IDE?)
I know ;). That's the output of lsusb..
2 IDE drives.  A dead IBM death star and a WD 160GB.
Then I would venture that your iPod is sda and that it's data is stored on sda2
no such device or directory.
Wow, this is getting a little serious. Maybe "sudo modprobe usb-storage" would create the device?
that command didn't give me any output, but the result is still the same. No /dev/sd*, no listing in fdisk.. :(
Well modprobe only gives output when there is a problem, so that is a good sign
To be honest I don't have an iPod, and when I borrowed one from a friend for data storage it automounted fine. The only advise I know is general USB HD stuff

well, I don't want to trouble you any further.. I'll just read the man pages for depmod and modprobe and see if I can get something happening.  An iPod should function the same as a USB HD though, correct?  If you know of any online resources, fell free to point me in that direction.
Yes, an iPod acts like a regular USB HD for saving data, it is just the adding and removing of songs that you need a special app for like gtkpod (unless you don't want to play the music on the iPod)
